title: leader march 25 2022
story: With Campbeltown Brass#s continued success in competitions throughout many years, it would be easy to take it for granted.But it is thanks to nothing but an incredible amount of hard work and dedication that it was voted the best band in the second section – just two shy of the championship section – at last weekend#s Scottish Brass Band Association’s Scottish Regional Championships.Adjudicators described Campbeltown Brass as the #clear winner# an amazing achievement made even more spectacular given the band has players as young as , the youngest performing musicians in the entire section.It takes a lot of dedication to attend weekly practices at the best of times but for the band#s members to maintain their high performance level despite all the challenges of the Covid pandemic, is outstanding.We should be so proud that the best second section band in Scotland bears the name Campbeltown, so let#s get behind the band and support its fundraising efforts ahead of its trip to the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain finals at Cheltenham in September.

title: letters march 11 2022 2 2
story: I would like to take this opportunity to clary my position regarding the forthcoming council election.After  years in office, my position has somewhat changed, as was well documented in the Campbeltown Courier in October .Despite myself and numerous constituents querying the decision taken, a satisfactory explanation has still not been provided.As readers will know, I always stand up for my local community at every turn and put South Kintyre first, rather than toeing the party line, when council decisions are made.I am of the opinion that this is the reason for the decision that was taken last year. I fully believe that local elections should not be about party politics and I have not and will not ever be a puppet for any political party.I am therefore standing at this election as an independent candidate.I have worked tirelessly to support and advocate for the community of South Kintyre over the last  years.I would like to thank everyone who has supported me in the past and respectfully request that you consider voting for me on May  so that I may have the opportunity to continue to represent you to the very best of my ability.Please note, due to current widespread and high level of Covid- affecting our community, I have taken the decision not to carry out door-to-door canvassing in the upcoming election.I have canvassed door-to-door in every election since , however, on this occasion, I feel it would be irresponsible to do so given the current situation.As always, please feel free to contact me should you wish any further information. Email: Donald.kelly@argyll-bute.gov.uk. Mobile:  .In the council elections on May  I will be seeking re-election to the council as your independent candidate for the Kintyre and the Islands ward.It is my firm belief that party politics at local level should not be important. What is important is having a strong local councillor who will help out his constituents and work day-in and day-out for our local area.With your support, I hope to continue to represent the Kintyre and the Islands ward.I am an Islay resident and have lived there my whole le with my family, many of whom work locally in the NHS and in farming, crofting, fishing and distillery sectors.I will always put my local constituents first, above any political party or special interest group. I have spent the past five years working for every corner of the Kintyre and the Islands ward.If you have a problem that you need help with, no matterit#s a big or small issue, then please don#t hesitate to contact me.I give the people of the Kintyre and the Islands ward my promise that I will work day-in and day-out for you.

title: pupils u13s in football action
story: Campbeltown Pupils stravelled to Clydebank to play BSC Glasgowon Sunday March , looking to follow-up on their draw with Busby the previous week.After a promising start, the Pupils found themselves - down at half-time, through a combination of poor defending, and also some good play from the BSC attackers.The young Campbeltown team rallied in the second half, and with a much better all-round performance, capped off with goals from Ryan Johnston and Ben Cunningham.Finnart #s The young Pupils# second away game in a row saw them travel on Sunday to play league leaders Finnart.The first  minutes saw the Pupils put in one of their best performances of the season, competing in every position, and they were rewarded midway through the half with a brilliant -yard strike from Ryan Johnston that found the top corner.The pace and strength of the league leaders# attackers started to cause problems, however, and two quick-fire goals gave Finnart the lead.The crucial goal came with the last kick of the half, with slack defending from the Pupils allowing Finnart to go into the break - ahead.The second half was a very even affair. The Pupils were unlucky to see a free kick from Johnston go wide, and an effort from Jack Green slip just by the post, but it was Finnart who put the game beyond reach with two goals in the last  minutes – goals that were very much preventable from the Pupils# perspective.This Sunday, the s will play a home match against BSC Glasgow , the first of three home games in a row.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2 2
story: If I had to ask you the question #are you tired # How would you answer We live in a culture that is becoming preoccupied with busy-ness and our daysDespite the noticeable signs of struggle in trying to keep up with the pace ofI have taken immense strength and support from two verses in scripture thatPsalm  v  says: Be still and know that I am God.Rest can be found when we stop and take time out of our busy schedules andMatthew  v  says: Come to me all who are weary and heavy laden and IJesus invites us to find rest in Him because He knows our human tiredness. He Himself experienced exhaustion, loneliness, weariness, anxiety, and stress.Are you perhaps feeling weary, burdened, tired, and run down  I would encourage you in the busy-ness of le to seek rest in the presence of God.

title: way to work is just the job for employers and candidates
story: .Jobcentre Plus has a long and successful track record of matching quality employers with quality candidates. Now, many highly-skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time, and are considering new roles in new sectors. Jobcentre Plus can quickly put companies in touch with candidates who can make a real dference to their businesses.We talk to employers and employees about how they have benefited from working with Jobcentre Plus.‘Working with Jobcentre Plus is a no brainer’: Jordan, Contracts Manager, Elite Scaffolding, YeovilElite Scaffolding – a family-owned business that is part of the Denholm Group, reached out to Jobcentre Plus in a bid to reach younger potential employees looking for an apprenticeship.#We initially approached the jobcentre, simply for advice and to askthey could place an ad on their system. We did not expect the extremely positive and proactive response we received from the jobcentre. The team was very helpful,# said Jordan.The support Elite got from the jobcentre was invaluable in streamlining and accelerating its recruitment process which would take up to five weeks.#Now, the jobcentre advertises our vacancies via a sector-based work academy.#Candidates attend a two-week course at Weston College, Yeovil, to gain their Scaffolding Operative Training Scheme and Health  Safety Certications, as well as to prepare for an interview. Now when we interview candidates, they already have a scaffold labourer trainee card and the basic knowledge and understanding of the scaffolding industry. What’s more, all this support via the jobcentre comes without the additional fees of private agencies.#Out of seven candidates, six were offered jobs and five have remained with Elite which has  qualied operatives.#The process was seamless and effective, providing quality candidates who were keen to learn.#Working with the jobcentre is a no brainer! As well as alleviating the burden of interviews that don’t progress into jobs, the savings in cost and time to get candidates suitably qualied are a bonus. It takes the pressure off our own resources and provides top quality candidates in the process.#‘Delighted’: Simon, Employer Adviser, Yeovil JobCentreSimon joined the Department of Work and Pensions as a work coach two years ago after  years in sales and marketing in the private sector. He became an employer adviser a year ago.Once approached by Elite Scaffolding, also based in Yeovil, he set up a meeting with one of its office managers and worked out a bespoke recruitment package.As part of the programme, he contacted the local Weston College and together they “built” the course content.#I arranged for the employer’s contracts manager to present to the class through an online  so they could explain what the business could offer them and what they we were looking for.#At the end of the two-week course, six candidates were offered a place on the apprenticeship scheme at a starting salary of £,.#Elite had exhausted all other channels to recruit and were delighted with the outcome#, he said.Moreover Elite referred other local employers to the jobcentre and Simon is running another sector-based work academy with a local roofing company.#If you’re looking to fill a vacancy, Jobcentre Plus can offer you a named employer adviser in your local jobcentre that knows the local geography for both employers and those looking for work.#The jobcentre has an incredible pool of talent. One of my Elite Scaffolders said it’s not just about finding me a job but changing my le…You certainly can’t ask for better than that.#Simon, Employer Advisor‘Welcome’: Samuel, JD Sports Apprentice, RochdaleSamuel’s career got off to a flying start with a six-month placement through Jobcentre Plus at JD Sports.“I left college in January . I didn’t finish my A-levels because I wanted a change. I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because it’s something that I’ve gravitated towards.“I saw JD Sports was advertising and I thought I’d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. Everything went through really quickly.#Continued the  year-old: “My team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel welcome and supported me. I spent six months on the placement and I got paid, too. It’s a proper job which was exactly what I needed. Day to day, I’d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me a whole picture of what it’s like to work in HR and I’ve been doing it ever since.“After six months, there was the option to stay on and I’m now doing an apprenticeship with JD. Once I’d finished with the placement I got started on a qualication – CIPD level three in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and I’ve now been there for a year. Now I’m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing on the placement. Jobcentre Plus helped me and now I’ll just keep going.”Samuel, ApprenticeJobseeker  Right now, a Jobcentre Plus work coach is ready to match you to your next job* – find out more at gov.uk way to work gdpr_consentltd " https:jobhelp.campaign.gov.uk way-to-work Employer  Is your business recruiting  With thousands of quality candidates gdpr_consentltd "Jobcentre Plus  can help fill your vacancies now*.*Eligibility criteria apply

title: help put argyll and bute on the platinum jubilee map
story: Events of all types marking the platinum jubilee are being recorded on a nationwide interactive map to showcase all the dferent celebrations happening across the country.There are ious ways that local groups and organisations can get involved – and there’s still time to start planning.Celebrations including street parties, #big jubilee lunches#, beacon lighting and many more can be registered on the interactive map.There have also been lots of other celebratory competitions, from creating a special platinum jubilee pudding recipe to knitting toy corgis.There’s an important Argyll and Bute link to one of the most prestigious competitions, which will feature in celebrations all over the Commonwealth.Inveraray’s world champion pipe major Stuart Liddell is literally playing his part in putting Argyll and Bute on the platinum jubilee map after his bagpipe tune, Diu Regnare, was the winning entry in a contest to compose a special melody for the Queen.Diu Regnare – Latin for #long to reign# – will be played by pipers all over the Commonwealth at sunset on June , with Stuart planning to play at Inveraray Bridge.#I have heard of a number of local groups who are putting celebratory plans in place for platinum jubilee events,# said Jane MacLeod, the Lord-Lieutenant of Argyll and Bute.#I’m sure Argyll and Bute will mark this unique and historic occasion in its usual enthusiastic style and full of the community spirit that the area is famous for.#I would encourage anyone who is planning a celebration event to make sure they register online – we can all make sure that Argyll and Bute has the place it deserves on the celebrations map.#Register your event, and find out more, at platinumjubilee.gov.uk get-involved-with-the-platinum-jubileeAnd anyone who creates a platinum pudding recipe, bakes a jubilee celebration cake or knits a corgi is being asked to email photographs to lord-lieutenant@argyll-bute.gov.uk so they can be featured on the Argyll and Bute Lieutenancy Instagram feed.

title: around the fairways 2
story: On a glorious sunny and windless day, that felt more like early summer than spring,  ladies took to the course to take part in the April medal competition.In the first group out, Elizabeth Marrison set the pace for the day coming home with a score of  .However, this was narrowly beaten by Lorna Cook in the following group who carded and took the lead.This score was then matched by Margaret MacFarlane in the next group home.Mary McKinnon, in the final group, surpassed all previous scores and carded the best score of the day of and won the competition.Result:  Mary McKinnon  Lorna Cook BIH  Margaret MacFarlane BIH. Lowest gross: Lindsay Garrett .Last Saturday in glorious conditions members gathered for the Presidents v Vice Presidents match.Stuart McAllister#s team ran out winners by three matches to one over President Eric MacDougall#s team.The course continues to benefit from the recent good weather with drainage work completed on the rd th fairways and the greens will benefit from some additional work over the coming weeks.The ladies have a nine-hole Stableford on Thursday, April , with the gents competing for the Fisherman’s Cup on Saturday, April .

title: calls for strong action against planning violations
story: Councillor Rory Colville sought reassurance that the authority would take serious action against unauthorised work after the council published a draft of its new enforcement and monitoring charter.A council official reaffirmed part of the charter which said that enforcement was intended to resolve a problem, rather than punish a mistake.The discussion took place during a virtual meeting of the authority’s planning, protective services and licensing committee on Wednesday, March .Councillor Colville said: #I want to seek reassurance, because reading about enforcement, it seems to lack any teeth.#We are almost bending over backwards to work with those abusing their position.#Can you assure us that we do take strong action when it is required #Council planning officer Peter Bain replied: #We do take breaches seriously. Our approach in the charter very much aligns with the Scottish Government’s planning legislation.#It is not intended to be a punishment – it recognises that development is capable of gaining consent and being brought under control.#But where we have developments which are unacceptable, we would expect to act with the power that is required.#Councillor Colville then asked: #Is there any indication of officer time which is taken up  Is this a drain on our resources #Mr Bain responded: #It can be. We have an underlying enforcement caseload, as there are minor breaches of control which take an element of officers’ time, to take retrospective applications and serve notices.#We have a resource of two full-time officers and we are facilitating enforcement by drawing on planning officer time.#When we get signicant breaches of control, that will give rise to resources we don’t have on hand. We need to ert resources to deal with them because they are time-critical to deal with the parties involved.#The charter, circulated in advance of the meeting, states: #Planning permission is required for most development that takes place in Scotland, with the exception of some minor works.#However, developers or householders sometimes undertake work without planning permission or fail to comply with the terms of planning permissions.#The purpose of planning enforcement is to resolve a problem rather than to punish a mistake. Any action taken has to be appropriate to the scale of the breach.#Councils have discretionary powers to enforce planning controls in such cases,they consider it is in the public interest and expedient to do so having regard to a deemed assessment against the Local Development Plan and material planning considerations.#Councils also monitor certain developments to ensure planning controls are being followed. Additionally, the public often alert the council to problems they become aware of.#

title: no joke as mokfest tickets on sale in april
story: Tickets for the August  - festival#s ious events will be available online from pm on April  and from AP Taylor on Campbeltown#s Main Street from am on April .This year’s headline acts include Elephant Sessions, Trail West, Aly Bain and Phil Cunningham, Fìobha Ceilidh Band, Brian McNeill and Calum Alex MacMillan with Ross Martin.There will be much more information on all the concerts and a full line-up for each event in next week’s Campbeltown Courier and Argyllshire Advertiser.Organisers have also announced that the festival parade willthis year, with a slightly dferent format the parade will finish at the Well Close where Kintyre Schools Pipe Band will open Up the Close, the Saturday afternoon open air event.This year#s festival will also launch a new event which is being organised by Kintyre Sea Sports from am to .pm on the Saturday – more news on this will follow soon.

title: skys the limit for chemical engineer with kintyre work placement
story: University of Aberdeen graduate Cameron Macgregor has joined space technology company Alta Range through the programme which helps companies by offering -month, well-paid work experience placements in a iety of industries.Cameron has an important and ied role in developing launch vehicle range control systems, primarily ground stations and their associated systems.He is one of  graduates who gained placements with businesses and social enterprises across Argyll and the Islands through the programme which supports organisations to drive innovation and Covid recovery activity and provides graduates with valuable experience as they begin their careers.Morag Goodfellow, HIE’s area manager for Argyll and the Islands, said: #The graduate placement programme is about matching the development needs of inidual businesses with the skills and aspirations of recent graduates keen to gain experience in the workplace.#It’s a great way to attract new talent into the region while helping businesses to benefit from fresh thinking.#Many graduates go on to full-time employment with the placement host.#We’re very pleased to see so many of our area’s businesses and social enterprises taking up the opportunity to recruit graduates through the programme, and look forward to hearing how they get on.#

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: brunton-musselburgh-children-star-bugsy-malone
story: Youth acting group Drama Mill auditioned  children for the show, and now has a cast of  children from North Berwick, Aberlady, Gullane, Cockenzie and Haddington, aged from eight to .Linda Kearsley Ross, Drama Mill director, said that the performance – the group’s first foray into musical theatre – was “ambitious” but that the children had loved taking on the roles of s New York gangsters.County children to star in Bugsy MaloneShe added: “Bugsy Malone was our first choice of play.“Drama facilitators Claudia Overton and Stephanie Wynne and I have all taken part in productions when we were at school and have fond memories of performing this play.“It’s ambitious to do it with such a young castbut our fabulous talented group have risen to the task.“This is the first time we have performed at The Brunton and we are so excited to give our youngsters the opportunity to perform on a professional stage.”The cast will perform the famous musical numbers accompanied by a live nine-piece band, whose members are all volunteering their time and talent.Drama faclitator Stephanie Wynne coaches the young Bugsy Malone castAnd the production will emulate the original  film, starring Jodie Foster, by using splurge guns and foam pies.Linda said: “There is something really fun about playing gangsters and molls, and using splurge to take people down rather than bullets.“Some people criticised that the ending is really abrupt, i.e. that they all become friends and sing a song, but I don’t think children question the ending – they believe bad people can become good people and that, as the words say, ‘ you give a little love then it all comes back to you’.”Tickets can be bought via    or thebrunton en-GB shows bugsy%malone events - Bugsy Malone is on at The Brunton on March  .

now.Subscriptions can be cancelled at any time.If you would like to make a further donation to Ardgowan Hospice, you can do so HERE.Linda Kelly, of Ardgowan Hospice, said: "We want to thank everyone who has subscribed to watch our exclusive audience with AC- event."I would like to thank the sponsors, Arnold Clark, Clyde Eats and Specsavers Greenock for supporting us."I would like to also thank The Greenockand Newsquest for handling the recording of the evening, and of course Martin, Vicky, Jed, Adrian and Gordon for coming along and supporting the hospice."We are extremely blessed to have a patron who holds not only the cause, but the people of Inverclyde really close to his heart."

title: path-linking-tyninghame-binning-wood-gets-go-ahead
story: Discussions about finding a route to connect the village and the nearby beauty spot have been ongoing for a number of years.Now, a step forward has been taken, with a short section of path beside Tyninghame’s schoolhouse approved.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council told the Courier it was still too early to give an indication as to when the path would be created.She said: “This is a footpath from Tyninghame village to an existing core path and for the next stage the council hopes to work with the landowner to explore funding options for the remainder of a path up to Binning Wood.”East Lothian Council undertook a number of public consultations between  and  as part of the development of its core paths plan.At that time, a route was proposed to connect Tyninghame to Binning Wood.Daniel Wight, from Dunpender Community Council, which covers Tyninghame, previously highlighted the importance of a path.He said: “As long as we’ve been here, there has been frustration that there is no way of getting from the village to Binning Wood, which is a major recreational destination for walkers and particularly dog walkers.“There is no way of getting there safely other than getting in a car and driving up, which is crazy – it is less than a mile away.”Under the plans, a poplar tree will be removed.The planning officer’s report reads: “The proposed whindust path would provide a link to an existing path.“The formalising of the informal footpath would facilitate rural recreation in the area.”

title: veterans-urge-people-get-bikes-raise-money-poppyscotland
story: Jack Regan, , who served in Iraq and recently retired as a ScottishPower linesman, united with former artilleryman Billy Morrison, from Musselburgh, to urge cyclists of all ages and abilities to join the seventh annual cycling fundraiser event, which takes place in East Lothian.Jack, who served alongside Billy in Iraq, said: “This is a fantastic day out, as well as a way to show our support to former servicemen and women and their families.“Veterans can be very reluctant to ask for help, but we want to get the message out that it’s only a phone call away.”Billy, , has already cycled  miles for Poppyscotland and raised £, as part of his  Poppy Pledge.He cycled the distance of Land’s End to John O’Groats around East Lothian and on a static bike in the Musselburgh Tesco store in the run-up to Remembrance Sunday last year.Returning after a two-year break, the Sportive has already raised more than £, to support current and former members of the armed forces and their families across the country.About , cyclists are expected to take part in the event on Sunday, September , sponsored by Fred. Olsen Renewables.Starting and finishing at Prestonpans Community Centre, three routes ranging from  to  miles will take in the coastal road to North Berwick, then loop round the East Lothian countryside.More adventurous riders will cycle over the Lammermuirs, dipping down to Chirnside and Duns in the Scottish Borders.Billy, who served in the first Gulf War and Afghanistan and now works as a Tesco delivery driver, said: “I’d encourage cyclists of all ages and abilities to join in, get fit and raise funds for a great cause.“I’ve been very lucky myself, but I see this as a way to give back to former colleagues.“Whenever I needed a bit of help, someone always stepped up for me.“That’s something I’ll always recognise and I want to make sure that everyone  who has served can get the help they need.”Gordon Michie, Poppyscotland’s head of fundraising and learning, said: “We’re very excited that the Sportive is ing to East Lothian and the Borders after a two-year break.“It’s always a sell-out event, so we are encouraging cyclists to sign up as soon as possible.“We keep numbers low to avoid the need for road closures, and the intimate and friendly feel of the event is one of its attractions.“The route takes in stunning coastal views and country roads, while the timed hill climb will challenge more experienced cyclists.“We’re incredibly grateful to Fred. Olsen Renewables for continuing to sponsor us this year.“This means  per cent of the sign-up fee and any sponsorship raised will go directly to our work supporting Scotland’s armed forces community.“We’ve already raised more than a quarter of a million pounds to provide vital welfare support to families across Scotland, from help with housing and employment to mental and physical health issues.”The Sportive is an ‘open road’ cycling event, meaning that no roads will be closed, in order to minimise disruption to the public.Participants on e-bikes and tandems are welcome to take part, while riders can have a free placethey are supporting a cyclist with a disability.Visit www.poppyscotland.org.uk sportive for more information or to register.

title: ultra-marathoner-moonwalk-charity
story: Neil Scott will line up in Edinburgh’s Holyrood Park in June as part of The MoonWalk Scotland.Hundreds of people will walk up to . miles to raise money and awareness for those living with breast cancer and other cancers.Neil, who works at the Astley Ainslie Hospital in Edinburgh, is taking on the challenge for his “wonderful mother-in-law Madge Wilson”, who was diagnosed with breast cancer shortly before the start of the coronavirus pandemic.He said: “She’s a really treasured part of our family – and quite a character – so the news came as a real shock.“Luckily her cancer journey was very straightforward.“She discovered a lump and was seen very quickly, then had really good treatment and, at the end, a positive outcome.“Madge is now almost  and one of the most caring people you could ever meet.“She’s recovered really well.”Walk the Walk’s MoonWalk Scotland is ing to the Capital for the first time since .The global pandemic had seen the gathering shelved but organisers are looking forward to walkers setting off at midnight on June .Those taking part are given a bra, which can be decorated, as well as a t-shirt with a bra pictured on it.Neil, who is secretary and a jog leader at Haddington Running Club, is no stranger to covering large distances and will be taking on the Full Moon – . miles.However, the dad-of-two, who will be joined in his training by good friend Margaret MacLeod, was sure the walk would prove dferent from his usual challenges.Neil, who lives in Haddington, said: “At the age of , this will be my very first walking marathon – I’m normally a runner and have completed a number of ultra marathons!“I know that walking will be a totally dferent experience from what I’m used to and it will be a real challenge for me.“I’ll be following the special training plan which Walk the Walk sends and I’m planning to get out on a number of long walks with Margaret.“I originally signed up for The MoonWalk Scotland in , but the event was postponed due to the pandemic and I can’t wait to get to the starting line.“I’m very proud to be taking part as a man – not everyone is aware that men can do The MoonWalk. And, after all, men do get breast cancer too.“I won’t put pressure on myself on the night – I just want to enjoy it!”To sponsor Neil, go to walk thewalk.enthuse pf neil-scott

title: politicians-praise-dunbar-dancers-raising-40-000
story: The Dunbar School of Dance puts on annual dancing extravaganzas in aid of the Edinburgh Children’s Hospital Charity .This year’s performance at The Brunton in Musselburgh featured nearly  children, aged between three and .Dancers collected more than £, and impressed the audience with a iety of dances.The dance school, which meets at Hallhill Sports Centre, has regularly raised funds for the Capital hospital and its success caught the eye of East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and South Scotland MSP Craig Hoy.Both politicians submitted motions at Holyrood highlighting the success of the dancers.Mr MacAskill, of ALBA, submitted a motion which read: “That this House congratulates young dancers at the Dunbar School of Dance on hitting a fundraising milestone of £,, after lighting up the stage for the last two decades and raising money for Edinburgh Children’s Hospital Charity in the process understands that a show on January , , saw the school raise £, which the ECHC will put towards CAMHS, pushing them to the £, milestone commends founder of the school, Julie Friar, on the fundraising efforts over the last  years and wishes Julie and all of the dancers the very best of luck with future fundraising efforts.”Meanwhile, Conservative politician Mr Hoy, who is also a councillor for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, submitted a motion backed by fellow South Scotland MSP Martin Whitfield .Mr Hoy’s motion reads: “That the Parliament congratulates the dancers at the Dunbar School of Dance on reaching the £, fundraising milestone on the school’s th anniversary notes that, on January , , dancers took to the floor at The Brunton in Musselburgh for three shows and raised £,, which took the total amount collected for the Edinburgh Children’s Hospital Charity to over £, understands that, traditionally, more than  dancers would perform at Dunbar Grammar School over three days however, Covid- restrictions meant that this was not possible, and further understands that, instead, the group, which is based at Hallhill Sports Centre, travelled west to Musselburgh to perform on the big stage, and performed a iety of dances in ballet, jazz, commercial, hip hop, contemporary and lyrical.”

title: view-vocalist-headline-family-friendly-music-festival-musselburgh
story: The National Trust for Scotlands visitor attraction will host Festhailes on Saturday, May , starring a line-up of Scottish acts, headlined by Kyle Falconer, lead vocalist of The View.Other acts set to perform are: Daniel Meade and The Basement Boogiemen Blue Rose Code Mark Sharp and the Bicycle Thieves The Ronains and Have Mercy Las Vegas.Claire Grant, the trusts Edinburgh operations manager, said: "We can’t wait to welcome visitors to enjoy Scottish music acts in the beautul grounds of Newhailes."Everyone is welcome at this family-friendly event – so come along and enjoy the music."Newhailes is hosting the festivalFesthailes will run from pm to pm and include face-painting, child-friendly fairground rides and food and drink provided by vintage food trucks.Taking place on the lawn in front of the mansion, young festival-goers will also be able to play in the newly expanded Weehailes adventure playground.Tickets are going fast, with more than  per cent already sold.Go to eventbrite e festhailes-tickets- to book.

title: postman-sacked-leaving-chewing-gum-garden-ornament-wins-17-000
story: Former Dundee football player Graham Harvey spent  years working for the mailing company and was based at its Prestonpans office on Ayres Wynd when his contract was terminated for gross misconduct in .The postman, who was  at the time, was caught by the homeowner, who complained to his bosses and handed over CCTV evidence of the incident, which also captured the worker driving without a seat belt and leaving his Royal Mail van unlocked.Late last year, an employment tribunal heard that Mr Harvey was unfairly dismissed and he has since been granted £,. in compensation for being fired.The judgement of the tribunal awarded £,. relating to the period November , , to November , , and the monetary award exceeds the prescribed element by £,..The hearing was told that in October , a customer visited the Prestonpans office to complain about the chewing gum incident.The customer also emailed CCTV footage to the office alongside a photograph and written complaint, describing the conduct as “disgusting”.But the customer also claimed he and his we “did not wish to make a huge fuss about it”.When Mr Harvey ed to work the next week, he was brought in for a talk with Jordan Cree, the delivery office manager for the office, in which he admitted to driving without a seatbelt and leaving  items of mail on his passenger seat but denied placing the chewing gum on the customer’s premises – he later admitted to lying about the gum.The tribunal heard that he was suspended at the end of the meeting pending “further investigations into an alleged incident where you have defaced a customer’s property”.A disciplinary meeting was held, at which Mr Harvey admitted all of the allegations against him.He described the chewing gum incident as a “stupid decision” and said he had done it “on two occasions at most”, while offering to apologise directly to the customer.He also admitted driving without a seatbelt in rural locations.

title: libraries-temporarily-closed-due-staff-absences
story: Staff shortages mean some of East Lothian’s libraries are operating on reduced hours this week.Ormiston Library was closed yesterday , while Gullane and East Linton’s libraries are closed today .Ormiston Library will again be closed tomorrowwhile Port Seton Library is shut on Thursday.The Port Seton Centre will close early at pm today and will shut at pm on Thursday and .pm on Friday.The café is closed to the public all week.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: “We are grateful to users for their patience and understanding at this dficult time.“We hope to resume normal service as quickly as possible.”The Courier had askedthe staff shortages were related to the coronavirus pandemic.The spokesperson added: “While COVID-related issues are continuing to present dficulties to council resources and staffing challenges there are dferent types of staff absence being experienced, as well as some vacancies we are hoping to fill.”

title: xmas-day-thief-sentence-deferred
story: Nicholas Cochrane forced his way into a house on the town’s Preston Road and made off with cash and a laptop.Cochrane, of the town’s Drummore Drive, also stole a camera and a quantity of alcohol during the incident on December , .The -year-old pleaded guilty to the theft when he appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last week.Sherf Alistair Noble warned Cochrane to be of good behaviour and deferred sentence for six months.

title: plans-luxury-dog-spa-haddington-withdrawn
story: Three planning applications had been lodged with East Lothian Council’s planning department for the former RS McColl store on the town’s High Street.Permission for a change of use from retail to financial, professional and other services was needed from East Lothian Council to allow the proposals to go ahead.The withdrawal of the plans came just days after they had been backed by the town’s community council.Members were unanimous in their support of Gary Connell’s proposals for Bow Wow Dog Spa.Therese Laing, from the group, said: “That’s quite exciting.“I don’t have a dog but that is quite popular and I think it will do well.”Members had agreed to submit a letter to the local authority backing the proposals.Drawings included with the now-withdrawn application showed a waiting area at the front of the former newsagent.Grooming tables, dog cages and a bath would have been created at the rear.It remains to be seen whether fresh plans will be sent to East Lothian Council.

title: dunbar-beauty-salon-given-green-light
story: Peter Paxton’s proposals for the integral garage on Dunbar’s Meaford Avenue were approved earlier this month.Planning officials noted that there had been no comments on the proposals from members of the public.Conditions were attached to the planning approval, including that the opening hours of the beauty salon were am-pm, Monday to Saturday.A statement submitted with the application noted that the applicant was the only member of staff and it was expected there would be no more than three clients each day.

title: aldi-launches-new-spirits-range-time-summer-including-watermelon-lime-gin

title: port-seton-womans-dogs-win-big-crufts
story: Erin Inverarity, a Crufts veteran having competed at the world recognised competition for seven years, was thrilled and excited when her two beloved dogs, four-year-old Springer Spaniel and Border Collie mix Neve and eight-year-old Springer Spaniel Sam, ed home to East Lothian from the NEC in Birmingham with a rosette each at the beginning of the month.Crufts, an international television event, attracts around , competitors alongside hundreds of thousands of visitors each year.Organised by the Kennel Club, the annual canine event takes place over four days and celebrates dogs from across the globe.Erin has had a love for the four legged pets for years and even set up a dog grooming business, Erins Doggy Day Care, in Port Seton almost four years ago.She explained the process of the categories Neve and Sam competed in, saying: "I compete my dogs in agility which requires the dogs to complete a course of up to  obstacles."I travel all over Britain to gain points and to advance through the competing grading system – grade  being beginners and grade  being advanced."The young Kennel Club is open to dog handlers under the age of  and the other is open to any age of dog handler."The open category is most commonly known for being shown on tv."The former Preston Lodge High School student said it was a "massive surprise" to her when her young dog Neve, whom she rescued from Ireland when the pup was just four months old, placed so highly.She continued: "This was Neves first time at Crufts and she competed in the Young Kennel Club Graduate Agility."This event is only eligible for beginner dogs grade -."She placed first in - year old Graduate Agility event and won the overall Graduate Agility over all age groups."Her other dog Sam, a regular at Crufts, competed in the open event called ABC.She said: "This stands for anything but Collies and consists of two rounds."Jumping, made up of jumps and tunnels and agility made up of contact frames."After the two rounds, the overall score is combined to have an overall winner."In the jumping round Sam finished fth and the agility round he finished second, which meant overall we finished second."She was congratulated by a number of people on social media following her success, with one commenter saying: "None of this surprises us - you out so much love and hard work into your furry beans - it’s a joy to watch - well done."Another said: "Well done Erin and all your team and very special to have both dogs show how well you and they can do."Erin currently offers dog agility classes at Power Paws Agility in East Fortune.To book in with Erin for grooming, visit https:www.facebook Erins-Doggy-Hair-Care-.For agility classes, visit https:www.facebook Power-Paws-Agility-

title: pharmacy-proposed-haddington-retail-park
story: GLM Romanes Ltd already has three pharmacies in East Lothian, including on Haddingtons Market Street.Now, the Duns-based business is exploring the possibility of taking on the remaining unit within the retail park, which opened last year.Already, Haddington Retail Park is home to Costa Coffee, The Food Warehouse, Aldi and Home Bargains.Construction work on a neighbouring petrol station, with shop, is also well under way.GLM Romanes Ltd would like to apply to NHS Lothian to open the pharmacy offering the full range of services.Pat Lemmon, vice-chairwoman of Haddington and District Community Council, could see the benefits of a pharmacy being located in the retail park.She said: “I suppose for people who may have walking dficulties it is ideal for them and for the new houses, but I would hate to think it was taking away any business from the unique little pharmacies and Boots we have in the High Street.“For the people staying in the area, it would be convenient.”Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, felt there were positives to the idea, including the close proximity to the East Lothian Community Hospital.He said: “First and foremost, obviously the fact that the building would be getting used is good.“It has been empty since the retail park opened and there would be an opportunity for two or three jobs I would imagine.”Before an application can be received, regulations require that NHS Lothian and GLM Romanes Ltd carry out a joint consultation with people living in the area.The closing date for comments in the consultation is August .From there, a hearing could take place at the end of  or early next year before decidingthe proposals should move further forward.The remaining unit at the retail park is , square feet and has planning permission for class three use – food and drink.A planning application would need to be submitted to East Lothian Council before any proposals got the go ahead.At that time, members of the public would also get the chance to have their say on the idea again.Details included within the consultation highlight the pharmacy could be open from am to pm from Monday to Saturday.It would then close at pm on a Sunday.To take part in the consultation go to www.nhslothian.scot.nhs.uk services pharmacies newpharmacyapplications

title: easter-big-top-circus-returns-newhailes
story: Between Friday, April , and Sunday, April , visitors to Newhailes will be entertained by comedy circus performers in the baby big top, as well as learning skills at the outside workshop.Circus shows take place at am, pm and pm each day and each performance lasts for about  minutes.Booking for adults and children aged three and over is essential by going to eventbrite e  A £ car park charge applies to non-National Trust for Scotland members.

title: driving-ban-motorist-caught-almost-six-times-drink-drive-limit
story: Sandra Forrest, , provided the “huge reading” after several members of the public spotted her vehicle weaving across a country road in July last year.Forrest was pulled over on the A near Haddington, where officers were said to have “strongly smelled alcohol” coming from the vehicle.Forrest was taken to an Edinburgh police station where she gave a reading of mg of alcohol in ml of breath.The legal limit is just mg.Forrest, of Whitecraig, pleaded guilty to the offence when she appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court earlier this month and was back in the dock for sentencing today .But when the case called defending solicitor Rebecca Weissgerber told the court her client had failed to show up for the social work reports previously called for due to her father recently passing away.The lawyer asked Sherf Nigel Ross to allow Forrest one more opportunity to have the report prepared before he passes sentence.Sherf Nigel Ross told Forrest she had provided “a huge reading” to the police and that he needed the reports done before sentencing.The sherf reminded Forrest she had been handed an interim driving ban at the last calling of the case and deferred sentence again to next month.Previously the court was told Forrest had been visiting her ex-partner in North Berwick and was driving back to her home when members of the public saw her driving erratically.Ms Weissgerber said the court proceedings had been an “extremely anxious matter” for her client and she suffered from mobility issues due to arthritis of the spine.Forrest pleaded guilty to driving with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at the A near to Monkmuir, on July  last year.

title: covid-scotland-facemask-law-indoor-settings-remains-easter-monday
story: From Easter Monday on April , the mask mandate will be downgraded to guidance for hospitality, retail, public transport, and other indoor settings  - such as hairdressers, gyms, and cinemas - for the first time since summer .The rules will be relaxed earlier, from Monday April , for some other settings such as places of worship and wedding or funeral ceremonies, however.Nicola Sturgeon said continuing to require facemasks by law for a further two weeks struck a "sensible balance" amid signs that the BA. Omicron wave in Scotland is beginning to peak or stabilise.The number of people in hospital with Covid fell from , to , in the past  hours The Covid threat level is expected to be reduced from medium to low during Spring, said the First Minister.Ms Sturgeon said: "This phased approach strikes a sensible balance between our desire to remove this one remaining legal measure, and the common sense need for continued caution - not least for the sake of the NHS - while this wave of infection subsides."I recognize that face coverings are an inconvenience. However, given all the sacrice of the past two years, and in view of the current pressure on the NHS, I believe the vast majority of people will accept that for a further two weeks this is a proportionate precautionary measure while we pass the peak of this latest wave."It also provides some further protection to those who are most at risk from the virus."Compulsory face coverings have already come to an end in all other parts of the UK, with England - which briefly reintroduced them in December as part of its Plan B response to the Omicron wave - becoming the first to drop the requirement at the end of January.  #COVID infections continued to increase across England, Wales and Scotland in the most recent week, but decreased in Northern Ireland.These high infection levels are driven by the Omicron BA. iant https:t.co zjZZxROXBX pic CSjbiIxM In February, Northern Ireland switched facemasks from law to guidance, but still strongly advises the public to wear them in enclosed public spaces such as shops, bars, restaurants and public transport.Since Monday, people in Wales have no longer been required to wear facemasks in shops and on public transport, but they are still mandatory in health and care settings. The latest surveillance by the Office for National Statistics  indicates that the prevalence of Covid is highest in Scotland - with one in  people infected - despite the ongoing mask law. The next surveillance figures will be released on Friday.Surgical and cotton masks are known to be less effective against the highly transmissible BA. Omicron strain than previous iants, although FFP and FFP masks remain protective. Ms Sturgeon said the Scottish Governments decision to delay the lting of the mask law across the board from Monday was taken to protect the NHS. She said: "We have taken account of the very high level of infection and the pressure on the NHS, and the fact that face coverings do provide an important layer of protection against transmission of the virus from one person to another."However, we are also mindful that the data may now be indicating a peaking of this wave of infection which should hopefully become more pronounced over the next couple of weeks."Source: Public Health ScotlandIt comes as weekly data showed a dip in Covid hospital admissions for the first time since the BA. Omicron wave took off in February, with , Covid positive patients admitted in the week ending March  compared to , during the previous week. Notably, the decline was most pronounced - down by %, from  to  - in the over-s age group who are more likely to be sick as a result of Covid and take longer to recover, impacting on bed occupancy. Among the under-s, admissions continued to climb, but these are more likely to be incidental Covid cases where patients are in hospital for other reasons. There were  Covid admissions for patients under , of which were children aged five and under who are not currently eligible for Covid vaccinations. The number of people currently in hospital with Covid - which reflects both admissions and s of stay - also fell signicantly for the first time since February, from , to ,. The majority are not in hospital with Covid as a primary diagnosis, but still require to be isolated which squeezes hospital capacity and results in delays to operations.However, Ms Sturgeon told MSPs that there are "grounds for optimism that this latest wave of infection may now have peaked". She pointed to daily data from testing which shows a % fall in confirmed cases over the last seven days which is "fairly consistent across all age groups", along with the findings from wastewater sampling which "also gives some cause for optimism". "It is not yet indicating a fall in the level of infection - but it does suggest that the situation has stabilised since mid March," said the First Minister. She added: "We will therefore continue to assess the data closely – including, of course, the results of the latest ONS survey due later this week."But we are hopeful that this wave has peaked or is now peaking. Indeed, this is being observed already in Northern Ireland which, unlike England and Wales, appears to have been ahead of Scotland in the transmission of BA.."

title: east-lothian-council-election-2022-50-candidates-standing-nominations-close
story: The deadline for nominations for the  East Lothian Council election passed at pm this afternoonand the full list of candidates has now been published, with exactly  names on the ballot.The current make-up of East Lothian Council sees Labour operate as a minority administration with nine councillors, the Conservatives as the official opposition with seven, and the SNP the third largest party with six. No other parties have any councillors.The list of candidates for this years election sees no party put forward enough candidates for a majority , meaning that either a coalition or a minority administration is guaranteed following the vote.Labour and the SNP are standing the most candidates,  each, followed by the Conservatives with seven, then the Greens and Liberal Democrats with six each.The ALBA Party are standing four candidates, the Scottish Family Party three, while UKIP, the Scottish Trade Union and Socialist Coalitionand the Independence for Scotland Party each have one candidate. There is also one independent standing.Voting takes place on Thursday, May , with East Lothian split into six separate wards and residents voting for the candidates in the ward in which they live.The election uses the Single Transferable Votesystem, where voters can rank candidates in order of preference rather than a single cross. Voters can choose to vote for as many or as few candidates as they like.The count will be carried out electronically on Friday, May , and the results will be announced later that day after the completion of the count.The full list of candidates, broken down by ward, is as follows:Ward  – Musselburgh Ward  – Preston, Seton and Gosford Ward  – Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry Ward  – North Berwick Coastal Ward  – Haddington and Lammermuir Ward  – Dunbar and East Linton

title: wordle-283-march-29-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter S and ends with the letter L.It has one vowel.It contains a double letter.What is today’s Wordle answer, Tuesday, March  If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now. The Wordle for March  is SHALL. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.“After all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.“Given this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I’ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.”
