title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327newshargey tackles digital exclusion through provision of free broadband
story: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey has announced the provision of free broadband for those facing digital exclusion as a barrier to work. The broadband support package will be available to eligible jobseekers through the Department for Communities’ Adviser Discretion Fund, a grant fund available to help remove barriers to employment that prevent people moving towards and into employment Minister Hargey said: “Digital exclusion has been one of the inequalities thrown into sharper focus by the Covid- pandemic. “More than ever, employers are posting vacancies online, with many having moved to online interviewing and more positions requiring people to work from home. “Therefore, not having access to broadband can be a signicant barrier to searching for, or moving into, employment. “I am tackling this by providing free broadband support which will provide broadband for eligible jobseekers who do not currently have the service.” Support for broadband through the Adviser Discretion Fund is available for a period of six months. The Fund can provide a non-repayable grant of up to pound,, in a  month period, to remove barriers to employment. The Minister continued: “The success of the Adviser Discretion Fund in helping remove barriers to employment has already been seen throughout the year, particularly in the uptake of upfront childcare costs, which I made available last October. “I am delighted that we have already helped around  parents with average upfront childcare costs of approximately pound. “This additional scheme will help remove similar barriers to employment for those facing digital exclusion due to a lack of broadband service.”

title: council commends autism friendly sessions at local attraction
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has commended a local business on the launch of a new initiative aimed at autistic children and their families. Commencing on Wednesday  March, Fun Factory Ballymena will host a series of quiet play sessions for autistic children, during which visitor entry numbers will be signicantly reduced, lighting will be dimmed and no loud music will be played. A six-month pilot of the initiative, which is supported by Council’s Community Planning Partnership, will see the sessions offered on the last Wednesday of every month between March and October from .pm to .pm . The sessions align with Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s strategy to make Mid and East Antrim an Autism Friendly Borough as part of its Community Plan. Partnering with a wide range of organisations, including The Fun Factory, Council is creating a strong, vibrant, safe and inclusive community in which local citizens, businesses and community organisations work together to improve the lives of everyone. Council remains strongly committed to ensuring Mid and East Antrim is an accessible, safe, welcoming and inclusive place for every person living in or visiting the Borough. In , it was awarded the prestigious ‘Autism Impact Award’ for six of its venues in recognition of “going above and beyond” to create accessible and ‘autism-friendly’ environments – including Seven Towers Leisure Centre and The People’s Park. These award accreditations were presented by Autism NI, in partnership with the Northern Health and Social Care Trust .Pamela, Manager of The Fun Factory, commented: “The Fun Factory is very much behind Council’s ambition to be as accessible and inclusive as possible for every person of every age, background and ability living in or visiting our Mid and East Antrim – it’s something we very much strive to achieve in our own business. “We passionately believe that every child deserves the chance to have a fun and enjoyable experience in an environment in which they feel safe and comfortable. Council has been fantastic in helping us to understand the challenges faced by autistic children and their families and supporting us to develop these new quiet play sessions.”For more information about the sessions, please visit www.thefunfactoryni. Sessions can be booked via telephone by calling   .

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220329newsbooster third dose milestone welcomed
story: The number of COVID- vaccine boosters and third doses administered in Northern Ireland has passed the one million mark. The milestone has been welcomed by Patricia Donnelly, head of Northern Ireland’s vaccination programme. She said: “GPs, community pharmacists and Trusts have all worked extremely hard to roll out the booster campaign, with the period in the run up to Christmas particularly busy. “They all deserve our heartfelt thanks. Because of the vaccines, we now have much greater protection against the virus. “All those involved in the vaccination programme are genuine history makers.” Booster doses have been provided from the latter stages of last year, supplementing the two primary doses already received. At the same time, a third primary dose was offered to people with a severely weakened immune system, which was then followed by a booster three months after their third primary dose. The latest tallies on Northern Ireland’s vaccination dashboard include , boosters and , third doses. Patriciacontinued: “While demand for vaccines is no longer at levels from the peak of the campaign, people are still coming forward on a daily basis for boosters and first and second doses. “It’s still not too late to get these jabs. Please do so - and benefit from the really important protection they bring.” The one million landmark has been reached with the Spring booster campaign imminent. In line with UK-wide guidance set by the JCVI, the Spring campaign will offer an additional booster dose to: anyone who is aged  or over care home residents and anyone aged  and over who has a severely weakened immune system. Further details can be found on NI Direct:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles get-covid--vaccination-and-booster-northern-ireland

title: wrightbus continues recruitment search with 50 new jobs
story: WORLD leading bus manufacturer Wrightbus is hosting a recruitment evening on Thursdayas it continues to bolster its ranks with an additional  staff after an increase in orders.The Ballymena-based company is launching the second phase of its recruitment drive ready for an increase in the production schedule after Easter. It has attracted hundreds of people to similar events held earlier this year, with numerous job offers made on the spot after express interviews.Wrightbus’ recruitment evenings provide prospective employees with the opportunity to look around the company’s Galgorm factory and speak to company managers and the HR team about potential career opportunities.The firm had previously announced it was looking to recruit an additional  people as orders for its buses flooded in. This time, it’s especially keen to attract more women.“We’ve taken on a number of new staff so far this year, which is fantastic - but we still have roles available that we need to fill,” said Wrightbus HR director, Nicola McCloskey.“Our staff work in great conditions on some of the world’s leading zero emission technology, which is helping to make a real dference to climate change.“We’re especially keen to get more women into the workforce, as most of the interest we’ve had to date has been from men. “I think there’s a bit of a misconception that the work we do here is all very physically demanding, but we’ve got many dferent roles across the factory.“We’d encourage anyone interested in joining us to pre-book a slot. All our jobs will be posted on the company’s website and social media accounts.” Wrightbus is at the forefront of the zero emission public transport movement. An increase in orders has seen production at the factory double in , with zero emission vehicles accounting for an impressive  per cent of all output this year.Wrightbus boasts excellent, clean working conditions, great rates of pay and fantastic career progression opportunities. The event will take place from .-.pm on Thursday March . Half hour slots are available to pre-book at https:wrightbus.eventbrite Previous recruitment open evenings held at Wrightbus have attracted more than  people who were interested in a range of jobs including production, quality, engineering and office roles.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220330newscalls for a time to say thanks during volunteer week
story: With the countdown now on to Volunteers’ Week , which runs from - June, Volunteer Now is calling on communities and businesses across Northern Ireland to get ready to honour local heroes by taking ‘Time to Say Thanks’ as part of a week-long programme of activity celebrating volunteering across the UK.   Now in its th year, Volunteers’ Week sees charities, voluntary groups, social organisations, and volunteers themselves come together to recognise the incredible impact that volunteering has in communities, both locally and regionally. This year’s theme - ‘A time to say thanks’ – encourages everyone to recognise the huge impact that people from all walks of le make on the lives of people and their communities when they volunteer. The week-long celebration, coinciding with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee, will include designated themed days showcasing the breadth and impact that dferent types of volunteering has played in local communities over the last  months. Each day is a chance to take the time to say thank you to volunteers across Northern Ireland – and Volunteer Now is calling for all charities and volunteers to get involved. With around , formal volunteers carrying out work with designated organisations and , informal volunteers, volunteering plays a signicant role across the region. Each year, volunteers across Northern Ireland carry out work worth more than half a billion pounds and contribute pound million to the local economy. Voluntary organisations in Northern Ireland do work worth more than half a billion pounds a year. As the lead organisation for volunteering in Northern Ireland, Volunteer Now is leading the charge to put Volunteers’ Week firmly on the community agenda, encouraging everyone to engage with the week-long programme of activity to say a collective ‘thank you’ to volunteers right across the region. Denise Hayward, chief executive at Volunteer Now, which coordinates Volunteers’ Week in Northern Ireland, commented: “Volunteers have continued to give so much time, energy, commitment and skills to the communities and organisations that they have supported through another dficult year. It is fitting that Volunteers Week  will give everyone the opportunity to say Thank You to everyone who has made a dference through their voluntary efforts.”  Volunteer Now is also calling for more people to participate in volunteering activity by registering with its online portal. Launched in , Volunteer Now’s revolutionary volunteering , in partnership with Be Collective, is celebrating its second anniversary, having registered and connected almost , volunteers with more than , organisations across a wide range of opportunities. The Be Collective  is the first of its kind to be implemented within the charity sector in Northern Ireland and aims to revolutionise volunteering and its impacts for businesses, community groups and iniduals across the region. The  cohesively connects volunteering, organisations, outcomes and social value through innovative social infrastructure and for the first time quanties volunteering contribution by giving iniduals and businesses a social “record”. “I’m delighted to celebrate the second anniversary of our Be Collective online volunteering  has really revolutionised how we connect volunteers with real time opportunities, providing support for communities across Northern Ireland and, importantly, delivering quantiable and demonstrable impact for organisations investing in their people. We’re delighted to see so many of our partners embrace this new  and we would encourage any organisation considering volunteering to get in touch with us and register with the . With a wide iety of live volunteering opportunities, there has never been a better time for volunteers, or those considering getting into volunteering, to find their perfect match”, added Denise Hayward. For more information on events planned for Volunteers’ Week in Northern Ireland, which runs from - June , please visit www.volunteernow or follow @VolunteerNow on Facebook or Instagram. For resources and more information on Volunteers’ Week UK, please visit www.volunteersweek.org

Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium NI Old Firm fans’ plans up in air due to PO impasseExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCeltic and Rangers fans at an Old Firm game. Credit: Andrew Milligan FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCeltic and Rangers fans at an Old Firm game. Credit: Andrew MilliganMark BainTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThousands of Rangers and Celtic football fans have been left with tickets for big matches in Scotland with one of their main routes of travel no longer possible.The impasse at PO Ferries means the regular sailings from Larne to Cairnryan are no longer operating, and fans who have paid out hundreds of pounds for season tickets, and who travelled every couple of weeks to Glasgow, have been left high and dry, unless they fork out for plane tickets or a secure a spot on a Stena ferry.And there’s a major problem looming over Easter weekend, with fans of both clubs hoping to travel at the same time for the Scottish Cup semi-final between the two Glasgow giants.This weekend, the North Ulster Federation of Rangers Supporters’ Clubs had been due to travel with several coaches to the Rangers v Celtic Scottish Premier League match at Ibrox Stadium — but there plans are in disarray.Charlie Connor, from the Limavady Rangers Supporters Club, said plans to travel this weekend have been abandoned by many.“There were several buses booked on PO this weekend but we got the call that the ferries would not be running and that it would be some time before they were.“All we could do is try to sell on our tickets. Some who had tickets for games have managed to get their cars booked onto the Stena service, but they’re few and far between.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “We haven’t had any further information and simply can’t think what solution there is unless ferries start running again.”Colin Scott, from Lisburn Glasgow Rangers Supporters Club, said the issues with the PO sailings had caused a major headache.“It’s not just the lack of routes,” he said. “The cost is too much for many supporters and this weekend it’s virtually impossible to get a flight that can get you to the match in time for the noon kick-off.“We will have a major issue when Rangers are in the quarter-final of the Europa League against Braga on Wednesday, April . We have tickets, but we can’t get there. We usually travelled by PO for the midweek games.”Stena Line has introduced extra sailings from Belfast to Scotland to help facilitate higher passenger numbers, but said the sailings have been booking up quickly.“We have brought in an additional vessel, the Stena Nordica, to run in conjunction with our existing two vessels on the Belfast-Cairnryan route,” the ferry operator said. “This has increased the number of daily sailings from  to  every day.“Understandably, all our sailings are currently busier than usual. We ask that all passengers ensure they book in advance online and check-in for their sailings within plenty of time before departure.”Rangers fans will by hit most by being unable to attend this weekend’s Old Firm derby, with local clubs getting more tickets for the home fixture than Celtic’s away support. But unless PO are operating against by Sunday, April , Stena could be faced with a headache as fans of Celtic and Rangers will all be trying to travel for the Scottish Cup semi-final on Easter Sunday.“Plans are yet to be finalised and will be discussed with Group Travel on how that will work,” Stena said.Related topicsRangers FCCeltic FCMore On Rangers FCWatch: Paul Gascoigne caught on title: ni schools facing drop in psychological support services
story: Graham Gault, Director of the National Association of Head Teachers in Northern Ireland. Pic: Peter Morrison. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGraham Gault, Director of the National Association of Head Teachers in Northern Ireland. Pic: Peter Morrison.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSchools in Northern Ireland are facing a drop in psychological support services for children.The BBC report that the Education Authority have warned there will be less educational psychologists available to visit schools due to signicant pressures on the service and an “unpredicted” increase in demand.Health Minister Robin Swann had also previously warned that children were likely to need more help for their mental health after the pandemic.Graham Gault is the director of the National Association of Head Teachersin Northern Ireland.He said the service was about more than just mental health, helping to assess children for a wide iety of complex needs including autism and dyslexia.Speaking to Good Morning Ulster, he called it the result of “a failure to invest” in the service and education in general.“We cannot expect to remove hundreds of millions of pounds from education funding and maintain the same level of service for children,” he said.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Gault said NAHT members were not convinced by claims the shortage had not been predictable.“There should have been investment in our educational psychologists, and I have to say the educational psychologists we have are outstanding.“I understand they are really struggling with their workload and devastated themselves because they feel like they are failing children.“They are not failing children, this is a result of a failure to invest in education”.A letter to schools from the Education Authority stated: Unfortunately at this current time the Educational Psychology Service is unable to provide the same level of support this year as in previous years due to the unpredicted rise in referrals to the service at all stages of the code of practice.As a result, your educational psychologist will not be able to provide the number of visits to your school that was planned at the start of this academic year.I fully understand that this action will cause disappointment and concern for you and for parents of children in your school.Most ReadHow Coronation Street actor Charlie Lawson saved the day at BBC broadcaster Emma Vardy’s title: wandering castlewellan child confirmed as safe
story: Police in Castlewellan carry out searches following concerns that a child was wandering unaccompanied in there area . FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePolice in Castlewellan carry out searches following concerns that a child was wandering unaccompanied in there area .Ralph HewittTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA young girl who was seen on CCTV walking by herself in Castlewellan in the early hours of Wednesday morning has been ‘confirmed as safe’.Slieve Croob Ulster Unionist Councillor Alan Lewis advised on Wednesday afternoon that the child has been found.“I have just spoken with police, I can confirm that the young girl has been confirmed as safe. There are no further welfare or issues of concern. There is no grandeur but it is always best to treat these cases as serious and de-escalate accordingly,” said the councillor.“I thank police and the public for their quick and efficient response, we can all take a sigh of relief that the child has been confirmed as safe, secure and well.”Temporary Chief Inspector Adam Corner added: “The young girl has been located safe and well. We would like to thank Community Search and Rescue and the public for their help and support in locating this child.”Police had renewed public appeals throughout the day to help find the little girl as they were “very concerned”, following reports of the child walking by herself in the Main Street area of the Co Down town at around .am.A missing persons report had not been issued for the child.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Most ReadHow Coronation Street actor Charlie Lawson saved the day at BBC broadcaster Emma Vardy’s weddingWandering Castlewellan child ‘confirmed as safe’IRA and Sinn Fein spy Denis Donaldson ‘rejected offer of new le from his police handlers’Man ‘ashamed’ to be from Belfast after auntleft lying in street for four hours waiting for ambulanceBullitt hotel owner says two rooftop rooms ‘completely destroyed’ after accidental Babel fireTop VideosPlayThe third and final series of Derry Girls starts Tuesday th AprilPlayWomanlatest arrest in connection with Carrickfergus reservoir murderPlayVideo: Blaze breaks out on Belfast Hotel bar roofLatest Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland man who threatened to kill New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern is jailed - title: sinn fein slammed for election launch at belfasts europa hotel which was repeatedly bombed by ira
story: Victims campaigner questions the choice of venue as Michelle O’Neill outlines her party’s stanceExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSpeech: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill addressing a party election event in Belfast. Credit :Sinn FeinPAThe aftermath of an IRA attack in May The Europa Hotel following a massive IRA bomb explosion in  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSpeech: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill addressing a party election event in Belfast. Credit :Sinn FeinGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA victims’ campaigner has questioned the use of the Europa Hotel as the setting for Sinn Fein’s election launch, saying it’s a venue the Provisional IRA “systematically bombed”.On Tuesday, Michelle O’Neill gave a speech at the Great Victoria Street hotel, which was bombed  times during the Troubles.She outlined Sinn Fein’s priorities ahead of the upcoming election including the cost of living crisis and “fiercely defending” the Good Friday Agreement.“The facts are that the balance of power at Stormont has shted irreversibly and political unionism must come to terms with the fact the world is moving on fast,” Ms O’Neill said.“So, while the DUP and the TUV are trying to take us backwards, our message is clear, we are only moving forward.”Commenting on the choice of venue, Kenny Donaldson, spokesman for Innocent Victims United said: Sinn Fein clearly don#t do irony, to bleat on about upholding democracy at the very venue which the Provisional IRA systematically attacked again and again, making it the most bombed hotel in Europe is brazen to say the least.However, due to the intensity of the Provisional IRA#s bombing campaign — and that of other terrorists, few hotel venues across Northern Ireland have come away unscathed by the Troubles.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up TUV South Belfast candidate Andrew Girvin said Sinn Fein’s campaign launch at the Europa was a “grotesque spectacle” given the setting.“Here we had the political wing of the terrorist organisation which repeatedly bombed the hotel in which they met daring to ponticate about democracy and respecting the will of the people.“There is nothing undemocratic about refusing to operate the Belfast Agreement structures which could foist a Sinn Fein First Minister upon Northern Ireland.“The choice of venue for this republican jamboree underscores the fact that no unionist should ever agree to take up the position of deputy to a Sinn Fein First Minister.“Yet just weeks out from the election both the DUP and UUP are dodging this vital question.Will they act as bridesmaid to Michelle O#Neill  Why is there reluctance to be open and honest with the public on this point ”The DUP#s Gordon Lyons said Sinn Fein#s election launch demonstrates their priority lies on holding a border poll rather than on helping families or rebuilding Northern Ireland’s economy.The party#s director of elections said: Sinn Fein#s rally was a show of strength for a border poll.“Whilst the DUP has a five-point plan to build a better future for Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein wants to win the election to implement their plan for a border poll.“There is a clear choice on offer to people whether they want a future focused on fixing our health system, tackling the cost of living crisis and replacing the protocol, or one fixated on a isive border poll.“When Michelle O#Neill talks about making history, we know it isn#t record levels of investment into our hospitals she is referring to. Now is not the time for ision and uncertainty.That is why this election is so important.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.Speaking at an election launch, Ms O’Neill said that Sinn Fein will defend but not renegotiate the Good Friday Agreement.The former Deputy First Minister said those who hanker for the past need to realise that there is no going back, only forward.Sinn Fein#s Stormont leader also described the DUP#s collapse of the Executive as political vandalism, although her own party also brought Stormont down in the same Assembly mandate.She said: When the Assembly, Executive and North South Ministerial Council were restored in January  it was with a shared commitment to deliver the public services, societal reforms and future that our people need and deserve.It was ambitious to form a five-party coalition Executive, but it was achieved, getting us back to genuine power-sharing, and thankfully so, because while everyone knew there would be challenges ahead, no one could have predicted that in only a matter of weeks that our Executive would be dealing with a global pandemic that would have such devastating impacts on every part of society, community and people#s lives and livelihoods.It is to the credit of all ministers from across the five parties that they responded and have worked with a unity of purpose, and unity of leadership for the past two years.This is what the public want to see more of — co-operation and delivery.Ms O#Neill added: Sinn Fein will be defending, not renegotiating the Good Friday Agreement now, or in the time ahead.Ms O#Neill said the May  election was the most important in a generation.Related topicsSinn FéinMichelle O#NeillIRACost of LivingTraditional Unionist VoiceGordon LyonsThe Executive OfficeMore On Sinn title: four officials at russian embassy told to leave ireland
story: Simon Coveney  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSimon Coveney By Jonathan McCambridge, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFour senior Russian officials have been asked to leave Ireland because their activities have not been “in accordance with international standards of diplomatic behaviour”, the Government has confirmed.It follows security advice received on Monday.The Russian ambassador was summoned to a meeting at the Department of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday.Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney said: “This afternoon, the Department of Foreign Affairs summoned the Russian ambassador to Iveagh House to advise him that four senior officials have been asked to leave the state.The Government continues to believe that diplomatic channels between Ireland and the Russian Federation should remain openSimon Coveney“This is because their activities have not been in accordance with international standards of diplomatic behaviour.“This action is being taken under Article  of the  Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations.“The Government continues to believe that diplomatic channels between Ireland and the Russian Federation should remain open.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “This is in the interests of our citizens as well as to ensure that we can continue to have a diplomatic channel of communication between Ireland and the Russian Federation in the future.“This channel of communication has been important in the context of conveying our strong views on the Russian Federation’s war against Ukraine, which we regard as a serious breach of international law.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming cc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abbea-b-a-fc-bffdfe_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming cc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abbea-b-a-fc-bffdfe_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming cc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abbea-b-a-fc-bffdfe_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming cc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abbea-b-a-fc-bffdfe_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Taoiseach Micheal Martin said he had received a security briefing earlier in the week PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTaoiseach Micheal Martin said he had received a security briefing earlier in the week Taoiseach Michael Martin said both himself and Mr Coveney had received a security briefing on Monday.He told the Dail: “Under the  Vienna Convention, four senior officials of the Russian Embassy have been asked to leave the state because their activities are not in accordance with international standards of diplomatic behaviour.“I received security advice yesterday. I know the Minister for Foreign Affairs also received security advice.“We met yesterday in relation to this with out national security team and under Article  of the  Vienna Convention we have taken these actions.“We nonetheless do believe that diplomatic channels between the Russian Federation and the state should stay open.“In the interests of us conveying our abhorrence of the war, maintaining diplomatic channels is a principle but also to protect Irish citizens in Russia.”We have sought to act in unison all along with our fellow European member states in the belief that that has the greatest impactMicheal MartinDuring leaders’ questions Mr Martin was urged by new Labour Party leader Ivana Bacik to consider expelling the Russian Ambassador to Ireland.Mr Martin said: “We have sought to act in unison all along with our fellow European member states in the belief that that has the greatest impact.“The economic sanctions have been severe, have been unprecedented.“The fact that that happened with the United States, with the European Union and others was powerful.“On the diplomatic side we will continue to work with others to again illustrate the country’s dissatisfaction, outrage at the war.”Article  of the Vienna Convention says that a state may at any time and without having to explain its decision, noty a sending state that  any member of the diplomatic staff of the mission is “persona non grata or that any other member of the staff of the mission is not acceptable”.Most ReadHow Coronation Street actor Charlie Lawson saved the day at BBC title: hong kong chief says resignation of uk judges is political
story: A general view shows the Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA general view shows the Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong By Huizhong Wu, APMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailHong Kong’s leader has rejected claims that the city’s judiciary is losing its independence after two British judges resigned from the courts in the semi-autonomous territory, citing increasingly oppressive laws enacted by mainland China.Chief executive Carrie Lam said she accepted the resignations announced on Wednesday, but insisted that “the rule of law has remained as robust as ever”.“The whole thing is a political arrangement,” Ms Lam said.“It is totally clear to all, that the British government officials and British politicians have used these means to damage our much-respected independent judicial system, and I feel that this is very regrettable.”British judges have sat on the Court of Final Appeal since Hong Kong was ed to China in , as part of efforts to safeguard the rule of law.But the UK and other Western nations say China has reneged on its promise to retain Hong Kong’s own social, legal and political systems for  years amid an intense crackdown on the city’s institutions following sweeping anti-government protests in ."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cddcd-ec-a-ef-ebebd_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cddcd-ec-a-ef-ebebd_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cddcd-ec-a-ef-ebebd_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news bb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cddcd-ec-a-ef-ebebd_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "The UK is withdrawing its judges from Hong Kong’s top court because keeping them there would ‘legitimise oppression’ in the former British colony AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe UK is withdrawing its judges from Hong Kong’s top court because keeping them there would ‘legitimise oppression’ in the former British colony Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Those efforts included passage of the National Security Law in  and changes to the electoral system that have effectively ended political opposition in the territory.“The courts in Hong Kong continue to be internationally respected for their commitment to the rule of law,” UK Supreme Court president Robert Reed said after his resignation from the Hong Kong court.“Nevertheless, I have concluded, in agreement with the government, that the judges of the Supreme Court cannot continue to sit in Hong Kong without appearing to endorse an administration which has departed from values of political freedom, and freedom of expression.”China’s ministry of foreign affairs said it strongly opposed the resignations on Thursday and echoed Ms Lam’s political accusation.“The UK, under the flag of upholding Hong Kong’s legal system, flagrantly used political methods to interfere with and harm Hong Kong’s judicial system,” spokesman Wang Wenbin said at a daily briefing.The security law, which outlaws secession, subversion, terrorism and foreign collusion, has been used to arrest more than  pro-democracy figures, including the most prominent political leaders and activists.Since the law was imposed, Hong Kong police have raided critical media outlets, such as Apple Daily, which subsequently shut down, with many of its journalists arrested.Most ReadHow Coronation Street actor title: ‘Doughnuts’ and speeding issues on Newcastle road
story: INCREASING concern about the behaviour of motorists on the Castlewellan Road outside Newcastle has prompted calls for a speeding assessment to be carried out in the area.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin have been contacted by a number of residents angry about the actions of drivers performing so-called lsquodoughnutsrsquo at the Maghera Road junction with the busy main road.The area is known locally as the lsquoCup and Saucerrsquo and the politicians calling on drivers to show more consideration.Mr McGrath said the Castlewellan Road was ldquoan incredibly busy route and claimed a number of motorists drove in excess of the mph speed limit.ldquoWe must be sensitive to the needs of residents who see at first and what is happening along the road, he said.ldquoWhile speed is an issue which must be considered, residents have had to endure night time activity including drivers pulling doughnuts in their cars at this junction. This is simply not fair on local families.Mr McGrath said a pattern was emerging whereby motorists in Newcastle sped along the Shimna Road from Donard Park and made their way up the Castlewellan Road.He urged police to get to grips with the issue to ensure people who live locally are no longer subjected to such behaviour.Cllr Devlin said the ldquoselfish actions of some drivers were not fair on residents, insisting that she and Mr McGrath will support those affected by the issue any way they can.ldquoWe shall be requesting a speed assessment of the area and asking police to consider monitoring any adverse behaviour, she confirmed.ldquoWe would appeal to local familiesthey do witness any reckless behaviour on the roads that could endanger lives to report it to police so they can gather all the necessary data..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Camera Club competition in memory of Charlie
story: BALLYNAHINCH Camera Club members welcomed Vitorrio Silvestri, from CPA Camera Club, last Thursday night to judge the entries which had been submitted for the annual Charlie Rutledge Memorial competition.Charlie was a much loved and respected founding member of Ballynahinch Camera Club and his great passion was mono photography.After Charlie passed away in  it was decided to hold a competition each year in his memory and what other genre of photographs could such a competition attract but black and white Vitorrio gave a critique on each image and, in some cases, demonstrated how they could be improved. He chose images from the following club members as the prize winners:st Terry Hanna, nd Muriel Darling, rd Frances Price highly commended and commended, John McCullough.At the end of the meeting, members were given a challenge for the next meeting. The challenge is to produce self-portraits using as much imagination and as many dferent techniques as possible. One such technique could be multiplicity mdash watch this space.New members are always welcome andanyone with an interest in photography would like more details of joining the club they should visit the club website: www.ballynahinchcameraclub..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch road bypass deay
story: FEARS are growing that the start of construction work on Ballynahinchrsquos eagerly-awaited new bypass faces a further delay.It was hoped that work on the multi-million pound scheme linking the Belfast and Newcastle roads would have started soon after a so-called lsquodirection orderrsquo was signed last year by Stormont Infrastructure Minister Nicola Mallon.It has emerged that just a handful of weeks before the Assembly is dissolved ahead of the May  election that she will not be signing a so-called commencement order paving the way for work on the scheme to start.However, Mrs Mallon has revealed that her departmentrsquos funding bid for the next three years included money to deliver the Ballynahinch scheme, explaining that the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget resulting in delivery timescales remaining uncertain.The bypass is included in a list of strategic and flagship road improvement schemes alongside Newryrsquos proposed southern relief road, bypasses in Enniskillen and Cookstown and junction improvements along the A.The latest delay in starting construction work has been criticised by South Down MP Chris Hazzard and veteran Ballynahinch bypass campaigner Francie Casement.Mr Hazzard has described the failure to commence the bypass during the current Assembly term as a ldquokick in the teeth for local residents and commuters across the constituency.He said that for more than two years, the people of Ballynahinch and wider South Down area had been waiting for a ldquopositive, proactive statement of intent from the current roads minister regarding the bypass.ldquoUnfortunately, we have been left waiting and the scheme remains on the shelf, the MP declared.ldquoAt just poundm, the project costs for the Ballynahinch scheme are relatively minor for a government department that boasts a huge capital budget of more than poundm per year. The Ballynahinch scheme represents excellent value for money and should have been prioritised during the past two years.Mr Hazzard said more than poundbn of capital resources has been spent by the roads minister and her department during the letime of the current Assembly.ldquoIt is hugely disappointing that a small, yet strategically important scheme, such as the Ballynahinch bypass has been left on the shelf. In light of the economic impact of Covid- and the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the commencement of this scheme would have been a welcome step towards improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of the local community, said the MP.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWe can only hope now that when the Executive is restored after Mayrsquos election, that the local community can have a minister in place who recognises the value of the Ballynahinch bypass and finally begins construction.Mr Casement said the bypass could help kick-start the economic regeneration of the town and provide the wider South Down tourism economy with a signicant boost. He said it was vital a start date for construction work is confirmed as soon as possible.A key member of Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committee for many years alongside the late Vincent Fullam, Mr Casement has never given up the battle to secure a bypass, which was first mooted in the late s.ldquoThe bypass is included in a list of strategic projects and is effectively ready to proceed. There should be no more delays. The scheme should have been delivered years ago, he declared.ldquoWhile the primary focus of the bypass is on easing traffic congestion, there are many other benefits, including reduced town centre pollution.Mr Casement added: ldquoThe new road scheme will also dissuade drivers from using built-up housing areas and rural roads as unofficial bypasses and, most importantly, help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre. We need to see work starting on the scheme now.A Department for Infrastructure spokesman said it was committed to delivering the bypass as part of a plan to aid economic recovery and community transformation, while addressing regional imbalance.He said that ldquofar from being left on the shelf, the scheme was being actively progressed much further by Ms Mallon than any other minister, with development work now substantively complete and statutory approvals finalised in July last year.ldquoThe next stage would involve commencing the procurement of a contractor but progression to procurement and construction is dependent upon the level of funding made available to the Department in future budgets, he explained.ldquoThe Departmentrsquos bid for the - budget included funds to deliver this scheme, however, the absence of an Executive means there is no agreed budget which means that delivery timescales remain uncertain.The spokesman added: ldquoThis is a priority for our Minister who remains frustrated that once again the absence of an Executive is negatively affecting both the people of Northern Ireland and our infrastructure..prettyPhoto

title: Carryduff landowner helps the environment with trees
story: CARRYDUFF landowner Rosanna Ballentine and her son Iain have received  trees to plant on their farm to help them enhance bioersity and create a habitat for wildle.The trees have been supplied from a partnership between Trees on the Land ndash a charity and not-for-profit project from the Green Economy Foundation ndash and SuperValu and Centra, part of the Musgrave Group.The project is part of a sustainability initiative from the retail brands which recently announced they will plant , trees across Northern Ireland over ten years.Mrs Ballentine welcomed the initiative and the assistance of SuperValu and Centra staff, along with central colleagues from Musgrave NI, who pulled on their wellies and visited the farm to help plant a mix of hawthorn, oak, birch, rowan and hazel trees.She said: ldquoWe are planting a new native hedgerow and a line of trees along the edge of an existing woodland to ide it from an adjoining agricultural grassland. Thanks to Trees on the Land, SuperValu and Centra, we can not only improve bioersity and create habitat for wildle but also soak up carbon.ldquoWe were delighted to welcome volunteers from our two local stores, as well as some of Musgraversquos central colleagues, to help with the tree planting.Already this year the retailers have sponsored , native trees, including  at the Carryduff farm. Centra Carryduff owner David Martin explained: ldquoAt Centra, we care about sustainability and wersquore very pleased to be involved with this project. It was great to be able to help with the planting and hear from Rosanna and Ian about the benefits that these trees will bring.SuperValu store manager Jim Brennan added: ldquoThis is a very worthwhile initiative and will create many long-term positive benefits for the area. We were delighted to help out and this project is just one that demonstrates our commitment to making a positive impact in the communities we serve..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan trio in the ‘Big Apple’
story: THREE young Gaelic footballers from Castlewellan had an important role to play in last weekrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parade in New York.Former Down goalkeeper Michael Cunningham and his team-mates, Paddy Boyle and Aidan Doherty, were given the honour of leading the Co Down contingent in the historic event which was watched by millions across the world on NBC television.All three played senior football for Castlewellan and are still highly regarded in their native Club.Michael was even given a name check by the impressively well informed commentator, who said he was looking forward to playing in goal for New York in the forthcoming game against Sligo in the Connaught championship.The opportunity to lead the Down contingent was described by Michael as ldquoan unbelievable honour and one which he would never forget.ldquoWe all feel very honoured and privileged to have been chosen.To experience the incredible atmosphere, the crowds, the bands, the colour and the cheers was just out of this world, he said.The first New York St Patrickrsquos Day parade was held in  mdash  years before the first similar event in Dublin took place in  mdash and has long been widely accepted to be among the biggest in the world..prettyPhoto

title: Celtic Bhoys lift the   Bobby Dalzell Cup
story: CELTIC Bhoys were crowned Bobby Dalzell Cup champions after defeating local rivals Ardglass in the deciding penalty shoot-out at Meadowvale last Thursday.A goal on the stroke of half-time from Ardglass midfielder Stephen Deegan was cancelled out on  minutes by the close range effort of Celtic striker Jordan McCoubrey.The teams refused to be split in extra-time and following the shoot-out mdash which went well into the sudden death stages mdash Blaine Connolly converted the all-important spot kick to gt his Hoopsrsquo side the victory.A large crowd turned out in Drumaness for the St Patrickrsquos Day showpiece between the current first and second-placed sides in the Newcastle Leaguersquos Premier Division.Adding to the pressure of the occasion was the alternating weather conditions, with the teams contesting the final in periods of sunshine as well as wind and rain.Nevertheless, Celtic kicked off the affair with the blustery conditions heavily in favour of their opponents.It didnrsquot take long for the tone of the match to be set as Ardglass defender Caolain OrsquoShea launched a very physical tackle on Hoops striker Jay Gibney.Ardglass enjoyed early momentum with experienced defender Neil Teggart seeing his wind-assisted free kick from his own half trouble Celtic custodian Nathan Curran less than ten minutes in.Celtic remained calm and soon strung their passes together through clever one touch football with eventual man of the match winner Conor Doherty in the thick of these sequences.However, Ardglass remained a threat and came close when Teggart clipped a cross into the danger area, although striker Michael Magee glanced his header wide.Stand-in Celtic captain Shaun Megahey attempted to play a through ball to team-mate Gibney, but on this occasion the Ardglass defence timed the offside trap perfectly.Celtic did come close when Barry Treacyrsquos corner kick was fumbled by Ardglass lsquokeeper, Mark Armstrong, although Hoops defender Paul Brady couldnrsquot dispatch the ball quickly enough before the danger was cleared.OrsquoShea continued his earlier eagerness and picked up a yellow card for a mistimed tackle before his team-mate, Magee, was unfairly clattered at the other end of the pitch, although Teggartrsquos effort flew past the wrong side of the post.Teggart continued to be a problem from set pieces as his free-kick delivery whisked past the head of striker Magee and out of bounds.Moments later, Mageersquos misfortune continued when he was shown a yellow card for expressing his disagreement with referee, Barry Mullan.After initially allowing the match to flow freely, referee Mullan clamped down on his decisions with less than ten minutes to the end of the opening half.Celtic defender Gary Carberry was the latest to enter the book for a late challenge on Ardglass marksman Magee.Despite this hiccup, Celticrsquos Carberry kept himself in contention for the man of the match accolade after he proved pivotal in stopping potential goalscoring chances from the Ardglass opposition on numerous occasions.As the half-time whistle approached, Celtic arms were raised as they appealed for the red card to be shown to Ardglassrsquos OrsquoShea, who may have considered himself lucky to escape an early bath after he was second to the ball.Ardglass launched another attack and it looked asMagee would have a free route to goal. However, Celtic veteran Brady recovered valiantly to prove he still has plenty of miles left in his tank.With the last attack of the half, Ardglass were awarded a corner and they took full advantage of their opportunity. Midfielder, Stephen Deegan, climbed high above the rest to head his effort beyond the outstretched hand of Celtic lsquokeeper Curran to open the scoring.As the second half kicked off it was evident that both sides would refrain from going for broke. A lot of the following ten minutes contained attacks, although both sides lacked a killer instinct and the match was heavily contested in the middle of the pitch.This is where Conor Doherty earned his post-match award for his performance, as he often won the midfield battle.Goal-scorer Deegan picked up a yellow as the weather took yet another turn for the worse.Celtic joint-managers Jason Galbraith and Matthew McKenna made the first of their substitutions as the clock struck the hour mark with Sean McMahon entering the fray in place of Conaill Kerr.Ardglass opted to put  men behind the ball in order to frustrate the opposition and waited patiently for their opportunity to counter-attack.Ardglass made changes of their own in the form of Jordan Finnegan before Celtic made a second substitute with the talented Sean Ferris making his way onto the pitch.Ferris made an immediate impact, adding another string to Celticrsquos bow by spreading inviting passes into his forward line.With just  minutes left of the , these Celtic substitutions came to fruition after the ball found its way to McMahon, who lofted an inviting ball into the Ardglass box which was steered home by the boot of striker McCoubrey.Celtic continued to mix things up as Corey McCartan made his way onto the pitch and gave a good account of himself with his tireless work rate.Despite this period of succession for the Hoops, the remaining minutes of the  played out finely balanced.Ardglass never let their headsand should be commended for their effort as they cancelled out any further attack whilst continuously seeking the crucial next goal.As tempers flared, the final whistle sounded and both teams prepared for extra-time.The highlights of the first half of extra-time came in the form of Celticrsquos Treacy picking up a yellow card before team-mate Ferris crashed his left-footed effort off the crossbar.During the next interval, both of Ardglassrsquo Magee and Celticrsquos Ferris threatened but they couldnrsquot do enough to get the ball over the line and it would be penalties that would decide the final outcome.Amongst the numerous penalties which took place, both Celtic and Ardglass players were ordered to retake their spot kicks.Firstly, Celtic striker McCoubrey saw his effort denied by Armstrong before referee Mullan blew his whistle after adjudging the Ardglass custodian to be off his line as the penalty was taken.McCoubrey fired in the retake and it wouldnrsquot be long before Ardglass substitute Finnegan would go through a similar course of events after he missed his initial penalty but converted at the second time of asking.Eventually, as the penalties progressed well into sudden death, Celticrsquos Blaine Connolly remained calm and converted the deciding spot kick to send the Hoopsrsquo support into delirium as his side were crowned champions.Following the conclusion, man of the match Conor Doherty gave his thoughts on his sidersquos victory.ldquoI thought we were the better team in the first half but then they snuck a goal before half-time, he said.ldquoBut, even with the wind we started to press on, it was a long  minutes.ldquoIt was a hard hitting game but Irsquom just glad we got on the winning side of it.He added: ldquoAll the penalties were top class, it was a really good shootout.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran, S Megahey , B Connolly, P Brady, G Carberry, C Doherty, B Treacy, P Casey, J Gibney, J McCoubrey, C Kerr.Subs: S McMahon, S Ferris, C McCartan, R Fitzpatrick, R Quinn.Yellow cards: G Carberry, B TreacyArdglass: M Armstrong, M Crangle, L McEvoy, N Teggart, C OrsquoShea, M Rooney , S Deegan, S-P Halpin, M Magee, C Kearney, C OrsquoConnorSubs: S Dorrian, J Finnegan, J Deegans, A OrsquoShea, B CrangleYellow cards: C OrsquoShea, M Magee, S DeeganReferee: Barry Mullan.prettyPhoto

title: Council official to leave for new post
story: ONE of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos most senior officials is to leave the organisation.Ms Dorinnia Carville mdash the local authorityrsquos current deputy chief executive mdash has been nominated as the new Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland.Her appointment has been confirmed by Assembly speaker Alex Maskey who is also chairman of the Assembly Commission.He confirmed that following the conclusion of the recruitment process, the Assembly Commission identied Ms Carville for nomination to the important role, which is instrumental in ensuring that public funds are spent wisely.ldquoIt is vital that all public bodies are held to the highest standards, said Mr Maskey.ldquoWhere public bodies, including Northern Ireland Departments, have not adhered to best practice, it is theof the Comptroller and Auditor General to make recommendations so that best practice is followed and lessons are learnt.Mr Maskey said Ms Carville brings a wealth of experience and expertise to the role of Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland, with a career that is rich in public sector audit experience.He added: ldquoI have no doubt that Ms Carville will serve the public sector professionally and diligently.The Assembly Commission tabled a motion for debate at a sitting yesterday when MLAs were given the opportunity to agree Ms Carvillersquos formal nomination.Ms Carville graduated from Belfastrsquos Queenrsquos University with a degree in Law, with Politics.She is a chartered accountant who trained and worked in leading private sector accountancy firms in London and Belfast, before moving into public sector audit, joining the Northern Ireland Audit Officeand gaining experience auditing a wide range of public bodies in Northern Ireland.Over the course of  years, Ms Carville held a number of positions in the NIAO including financial audit director and director of corporate services.In this position, she was the technical director providing technical audit advice to the Comptroller and Auditor General and the Local Government Auditor and represented the NIAO on the Public Audit Forum with colleagues from the audit offices in England, Wales and Scotland.Following the review of public administration, Ms Carville moved into local government as Director of Corporate Services at Newry Mourne and Down Council in .She is the local authorityrsquos senior financial officer and is also responsible for a wide range of corporate services including audit, human resources, legal and compliance, communications and marketing and capital projects.She is responsible for the organisationrsquos Audit and Strategy, Policy and Resources committees. Since February, she has been acting chief executive, deputising for Mrs Marie Ward.Ms Carville also holds a number of voluntary roles in the public sector as well as the voluntary and community sector, including as a Board Trustee for Belfast and Lisburn Womenrsquos Aid..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar girl going for chop
story: GENEROUS Crossgar girl Lily Magee is chopping off her long locks for a very good cause.The  year-old is raising money for the Little Princess Trust, a charity which provides a real hair wig to any child who has lost theirs due to cancer.A pupil at St Brigidrsquos Primary School in Downpatrick, Lily has already raised more than pound on her fundraising page.Her mother, Laura, explained that her daughter has been wanting to have her hair cut for some time.ldquoHer hair is down past her hip and she plans to get cm of it cut, leaving her with shoulder- hair, said Mrs Magee.ldquoShe hasnrsquot had her hair cut since the first lockdown. Itrsquos got so long that itrsquos a big unmanageable and she canrsquot put in her own hair bobble.ldquoLily has been wanting to get it cut for a while now. We saw that other local girls had their hair cut for The Little Princess Trust and we decided to wait until we could raise money as well as getting her hair cut at the same time.Lily, older sister to brothers Louis and Leo, will be getting the big chop at Precious Hair Design in Downpatrick on April .She added: ldquoThis is a big deal for me as I love having long hair. Any donation, however small is greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for your contribution. I hope I can help to make someone happy in my own small way.To support Lily and The Little Princess Trust please visit Lilyrsquos Locks Get The Chop! on www.gofundme..prettyPhoto

title: Down relegated from Division 2 following loss to struggling Cork side
story: DOWN senior footballersrsquo torrid campaign has ended in relegation following the Mourne sidersquos loss to Cork on Sunday.James McCartan has yet to register a league win since recapturing his managerial role ndash with five losses and one draw ndash and now his attention turns to saving Down from further despair.The relegation means the Mourne men will hope to rebuild and reset next year in Division , although the immediate worry now is the possibility of playing second-tier championship football. To avoid this, Down must manufacture a route to an Ulster final.It was a scrap for survival at Paacuteirc Uiacute Chaoimh as both the hosts and visitors looked to register their first victory to escape the immediate .Unfortunately for Down, Cork corner-forward Steven Sherlock was on top form and constantly proved a threat in front of goal.The St Finbarrrsquos footballer, who recently reached the All-Ireland club semi-finals, ended the match with a personal tally of -, a mere five points off Downrsquos overall scoring.It was anyonersquos game during the opening quarter with both sides exchanging points but neither increasing their lead past the minimum.Down managed the windy conditions well but were dealt an early blow when Niall McParland exited the pitch due to injury with just  minutes played and moments later it would go from bad to worse.A Cork goal from Sherlock gave his side breathing space and by half-time, it was this score which proved the dference as Down trailed - to -.Darren OrsquoHagan and Anthony Doherty kicked over for Down in the opening minutes of the second half after Cork had added more points to their tally.Down were given renewed le when Tiernan Rushe struck the back of the net, reducing the deficit to a single score.However, the next three scores went in the way of Cork, two of which left the boot of the impressive Sherlock.To the Mourne sidersquos credit, they replied with a trio of unanswered points but they were still hoping to close the gap and the clock was quickly ticking down.Despite their efforts, Down just couldnrsquot do enough to pull ahead after the interval and the contest ended with the Mourne side trailing by four.This timely win for Cork sets them up fora relegation play-off with Offaly whilst Down play out their remaining Division  fixture against Clare at Paacuteirc Esler on Sunday.This weekendrsquos clash means little as the Mourne outfitrsquos fate has been sealed, although a win on home soil may gt the players with a much needed confidence boost ahead of their Ulster campaign.Cork: M Martin K OrsquoDonovan, K Flahive, K Histon J Cooper, R Maguire, M TaylorI Maguire, C OrsquoCallaghanD Dineen , E McSweeney, J OrsquoRourkeS Sherlock , B Hurley, C OrsquoMahony .Subs: T Walsh for HistonB Murphy for SherlockM Croninfor HurleyC Kiely for McSweeneyJ Grimes for OrsquoRourke .Down: R Burns P Fegan, F McElroy, G Collins D OrsquoHagan , C Poland, C DohertyA Doherty, N McParland A Morgan, L Kerr, R McEvoyA Gilmore , P Havern , C Quinn .Subs: K McKernan for McParlandT Rushefor QuinnG McMahon for BurnsR OrsquoHigginsfor Morgan .Referee: B Grfin ..prettyPhoto

title: Down U
story: DOWN U- girls came into their third competitive match weekend looking to bounce back from two defeats in match day two.Playing at home in Liatroim gave the local girls and management a great incentive to get back to winning ways.The opening game of the weekend against Tyrone played out in dry but windy conditions. Down looked to take advantage of playing with this wind in the first half and were getting good scores on the board.However, Tyrone stayed in the game with two goals to leave the half time score - to - in favour of Down.Tightening up the midfield at half-time and with Down now playing against the wind, the Mourne side took the game to Tyrone. The match was very open and for every half chance that went in for Down, Tyrone missed theirs.In the end, Down ran out deserved easy winners. Final score: Down - Tyrone -.Scorers for Down were Grace McMullan , Anna McArdle , Isa McCarron , Clodagh Simpson , Orla Owensand Annie McEvoy .Good performances all-round the pitch. Best performers for Down were Annie McEvoy, Holly Donnelly, Anna McArdle, Eloise Austin, Isa McCarron, Grace McMullan and captain Orla Owens but it was Zara Kelly who took the player of the match award.In the next contest against Monaghan, Down played against the wind in the first half. Making  changes to the starting teams from the Tyrone match meant all  girls in the  got starting a game.The match was very tight from the off and was a very low scoring affair with very little clearcut goal-scoring opportunities.In a tight first half, Down were happy to come in at the interval with a score from Cliodhna McGrath, who notched a great point from open play.In the second half, the Mourne side introduced a few fresh legs again as they aimed to take advantage of the wind.Although Down initially outscored their Monaghan counterparts - to -, the visitors stayed in the match and continuously looked for goals.Some frantic defending and some very solid goalkeeping kept Monaghan out and in the end the local girls came through with a - to - win.The tightest of wins but well deserved on the day. Scorers for Down were Holly Donnelly , Lucia Keane , Grace Kellyand Cliodhna McGrath .Again a solid effort from all the girls in this match, but the best performers were Zara Greenan in nets, Ellen Farrell, Helen McGeough, Daire OrsquoShea, Hannah Cassin, Evie McHugh, Lucia Keane and captain Aoe Wolfe.However, it was Grace Kelly who took the player of the match award. Two good wins, six more points on the board but most importantly, another couple of solid performances from the squad..prettyPhoto

title: East Down enjoy St Patrick’s Day
story: WITH St Patrickrsquos Day offering a midweek holiday for many, what better way to spend it than running in a race A few East Down AC members travelled to Belfast to take part in the Craic K which is described as an urban road race taking in the city sights.It was an early start at am and while it was nippy at first, it soon warmed up.The route wasnrsquot too hilly apart from the last couple of kilometres leading into the finish at Ormeau Park and there was good support from the crowd so it was an enjoyable event.Deirdre Weatherall had a storming run in . which placed her rd out of . Clare Carson came in in ., breaking  minutes with ease.Donal Smith, who is in the midst of running every day for  days in the lead up to his th birthday, was happy to have company to tick a day off and was pleased with his . as part of his comeback venture.Kevin Kelly was out as a pacer and encourager and finished comfortably and smiling. All agreed that it was a good day out.On Saturday Sam Anderson, as part of her build up to Belfast Marathon, took on the Larne Ten Miles.The coast was spectacular in the sunshine and she felt that the views helped the time to pass while running.She clocked ., which she was happy with, but more importantly felt comfortable with the distance which will boost her confidence no end.The Fallows Race ndash the second round of the NI Mountain Running AssociationChampionships ndash took place the same day as Larne.Starting in Kilbroney Forest Park in Rostrevor, the route then took the runners out on to Slieve Martin with m of climbing in the km distance.The first early climb took about  minutes for the front pack so it was tough from the get go.Timothy Johnston of Mourne Runners took the overall win in ... East Down AC was well represented by Aaron McGrady.Having come third in Jimmyrsquos Ten the week previous, he might have been excused for taking the weekend off but he couldnrsquot resist the mountains.It was a perfect day, dry and bright with blue skies so the scenery was at its best.He kept up with the lead bunch for well into an hour of racing but the second big climb took its toll and he was left hanging on for the finish.At one stage he was third behind Jonathan Scott but a pass by Adam Cunninghamput him into fourth.Aaron finished in .., approximately two minutes behind the leader which is a commendable performance.Despite missing podium, he thoroughly enjoyed his race and is looking forward to the next outing.With Jimmyrsquos Ten done and dusted, East Down Athletics Club is getting back to business as usual.The annual membership night takes place next Monday in the clubrooms.Both ing and new adult members are welcome .-.pm to sign up for the year ahead.If you are considering joining for the first time and want to find out more, please contact membership@eastdownac.The junior section is at capacity so unfortunately only current athletes are invited to renew at this time. Sign on from .-.pm.There are lots of races looming from K to marathon and beyond so have a look at the fixture list at https:athleticsni.org Fixtures to set yourself a spring goal and then get yourself out the door and get running.It is the best time of the year to enjoy the benefits of sport..prettyPhoto

title: Farmers opposed to Poots%2C says MP
story: AN overwhelming majority of farmers who responded to future farming proposals outlined by Stormont Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots have rejected the new policy direction, according to South Down MP Chris Hazzard.He said that in recent days, it has been revealed that over % of farmersrsquo responses were critical of the ministerrsquos views for the future of farming.The MP said that, having talked to many local farmers across the constituency over recent months, he was ldquonot at all surprised by the news.ldquoIt was clear that the DUP agriculture ministerrsquos plans undermine our small family farms, ignore our sheep farmers and penalise those who farm our hills and mountains, suggested Mr Hazzard.ldquoUnder these controversial proposals, , small farms below  hectares will be denied funding, including many of our local farms here in South Down. This is totally unfair and, given the huge backlash, the ministerrsquos plans must now be scrapped.Also this week, Mr Hazzardrsquos Sinn Fein colleague, Cathy Mason, who is one of the partyrsquos South Down Assembly election candidates, has urged Mr Poots to intervene to help farmers with a financial package to alleviate the rising costs of feed and fertiliser."Farmers and their families are, like everyone , being impacted with the cost of living crisis. They are facing increased costs for food, energy and fuel in tandem with specic business costs with spiralling increases to the cost of feed and fertilisers. This is having a serious impact on many farmers and their families, she said.ldquoThese implications would have a devastating impact on our farmers in South Down who have little option but to use red diesel in their tractors and other agriculture machinery used for farming and food production.ldquoThis increase in red diesel cost, in addition to the uncertainty on Brexit and plummeting farm gate prices, will place serious strain on farmers.This is a problem that looks certain to continue and will be exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine which is a main supplier of these products.Mrs Mason said Mr Poots needed to intervene and ldquoprovide support, including a financial package, to help farmers through this crisis..prettyPhoto

title: Forsythe selected for DUP in South Down
story: THE DUP has formally selected its local Assembly election candidates to contest the May election.Diane Forsythe will be the partyrsquos standard bearer in South Down, while Crossgarrsquos Harry Harvey is one of three runners in Strangford where he is joined by Michelle McIlveen and Peter Weir.Earlier this year, Mrs Forsythe was chosen ahead of sitting MLA Jim Wells to contest the South Down seat and is looking forward to the election.ldquoI am delighted to have been selected to contest the Assembly election in South Down for the DUP, she said.ldquoIt is an honour and privilege to have the opportunity to represent this area where I live.ldquoWe are a thriving, vibrant area which I want to do my best to enhance and grow. We have so many opportunities across our industries, fishing, farming, manufacturing and many more.I want to work for everyone to secure improved investment in all of these sectors to boost this area and make us a central tourist attraction for the country.Mrs Forsythe said she wanted to help everyone in the constituency ldquowhere many are struggling and need support to access services.She continued: ldquoOur healthcare, roads infrastructure and support for working families in the squeezed middle of society need improvement. I want to be their voice in Stormont to make le better, she continued.ldquoI grew up in Ballymartin and am raising my three primary school aged children here.
